channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Nuclear Agency Leader Signals Progress on Hurdle to Accord With Iran
item.description: Completing an assessment on Iran’s suspected past nuclear work by December might help speed up lifting of sanctions, and remove a major hurdle in the talks.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Mohammad Javad Zarif, Iran’s foreign minister, during a meeting with Secretary of State John Kerry as part of nuclear negotiations in Vienna on Friday.

item.title: Fund in China Aims to Stabilize Stock Markets
item.description: The country’s biggest brokerage firms unveiled a government-backed plan to buy shares starting on Monday.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER and CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Syria Forces and Hezbollah Attack Insurgents Near Lebanon
item.description: Government forces and their allies in the Lebanese Shiite group began an offensive in Zabadani, a mountain town.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: Afghan Forces Battle Taliban as Lawmakers Reject Defense Minister
item.description: Casualties from the battle in Wardak Province were said to be high, and senior officials criticized security forces’ response as slow and ineffective.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: French Honors for an American Veteran of the ‘Monuments Men’
item.description: Harry L. Ettlinger rescued a Rembrandt self-portrait in World War II. On Friday, he was among more than 20 veterans honored in Manhattan by French officials.
item.dc:creator: ILEANA NAJARRO
item.media:description: Jean-Yves Le Drian, the French defense minister, embraced a newly decorated veteran at a ceremony honoring World War II service members at South Street Seaport in Manhattan on Friday.

item.title: Survivor of ’05 London Subway Attack Is on Antiterror Mission
item.description: Gill Hicks, who lost her legs in a bombing and now runs a counterextremism group, says people must learn empathy with terrorists to learn how to defeat them.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:credit: Maja Daniels for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gill Hicks on Tuesday in London at the King’s Cross subway stop where she was wounded 10 years ago in a bombing.

item.title: An American Tip to German Spies Points to a More Complex Relationship
item.description: The Obama administration risked exposing its surveillance out of concern over a perceived security breach, leading to an official’s demotion and to widespread German anger.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE, MELISSA EDDY, DAVID E. SANGER and ERIC SCHMITT.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Surrogate Children Win Legal Recognition
item.description: France’s highest court, the Court of Cassation, on Friday granted legal recognition to surrogate children, in a major turnaround that will make their daily lives easier.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: World War II Tank Is Seized From Collector
item.description: The German authorities seized a 45-ton Panzer tank, a flak cannon and multiple other World War II-era military weapons in a raid on a 78-year-old collector’s home.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Netherlands: Protests Over a Death in Police Custody
item.description: The Dutch police arrested about 200 people Thursday night and Friday morning for disregarding a ban on public assembly in The Hague rioting after the death of a man in police custody.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Liberia: 200 Reportedly Had Contact With Ebola Victim
item.description: The World Health Organization reported Friday that nearly 200 people had been in contact with a 17-year-old in Liberia who was confirmed to have died of Ebola.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Calls to Oust Ecuador’s President Flare Before Visit by the Pope
item.description: Ecuador’s government and opposition have both been using Francis’ imminent arrival to get their messages across, spurring complaints that a historic event is being politicized.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: Protesters chanted slogans against President Rafael Correa during an march in Quito, Ecuador, on Thursday night.

item.title: Mindful of Greece, Ukraine Is in a Rush to Line Up Debt Relief
item.description: In a bid to avoid continuous negotiations with creditors, the Ukrainian government (with the I.M.F.’s support) is deep in debt talks, pressing investors to accept a bailout deal — but investors are resistant.
item.category: Franklin Templeton Limited Duration Income Trust|FTF|AMEX
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: The former Ukraine president, Viktor F. Yanukovych, who was overthrown last year.

item.title: In Greek Referendum Campaign, a Barrage of Doomsday Ads
item.description: With the referendum on whether to accept a eurozone bailout package set for Sunday, supporters of both sides are invoking frightening scenarios.
item.dc:creator: SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:description: A Greek Orthodox priest giving money to a man on a street in Thessaloniki, Greece, on Friday.

item.title: ISIS Destroys More Artifacts in Syria and Iraq
item.description: Islamic State militants said they had smashed statues from the ancient city of Palmyra in Syria, and antiquities experts said a 13th-century tomb in Iraq was wrecked.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE and MAHER SAMAAN

item.title: How Iceland Emerged From Its Deep Freeze
item.description: Unemployment is 4 percent, the International Monetary Fund is predicting 4.1 percent G.D.P. growth for 2015, and tourism is booming.
item.dc:creator: JENNY ANDERSON
item.media:credit: Bara Kristinsdottir for The New York Times
item.media:description: Reykjavik, the capital of Iceland. The country has a population of 320,000.

item.title: French President Denies Julian Assange’s Request for Protection
item.description: In a letter, the WikiLeaks co-founder said that he sensed an openness to being granted asylum and that he had a child whose mother is French.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: As Referendum Looms, Greece’s Tourism Industry Holds Its Breath
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of Greeks make a living in tourism, and though officials say visits have been steady, economic tumult in the high season has many worried.
item.dc:creator: ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Plan to Resettle Hong Kongers in Northern Ireland? Surely You Jest
item.description: A proposal discussed by British officials in the early 1980s may have been a joke, but it highlighted concerns in Hong Kong about the impending handover and in Northern Ireland about ongoing sectarian unrest.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The handover ceremony to mark Hong Kong's return to Chinese sovereignty on July 1, 1997.

item.title: Doctors Without Borders Hospital Raided in Afghanistan
item.description: The humanitarian group condemned a “violent intrusion” that it said had been conducted by Afghan military commandos in Kunduz.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN and AHMAD SHAKIB
